thread.title: Tony Abbott, Joe Hockey, Kevin Andrews on the backbench
thread.title_full: Tony Abbott, Joe Hockey, Kevin Andrews on the backbench | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The Advertiser

author: Malcolm Farr
title: Tony Abbott, Joe Hockey, Kevin Andrews on the backbench
text:
THE three walking wounded from the Liberal leadership scrap finally came together in Parliament today and the greetings they accepted were carefully selected.
Four weeks after Malcolm Turnbull challenged and defeated Tony Abbott, the players in that political drama got back to their paid day jobs as elected representatives.
Just before Question Time former prime minister Tony Abbott entered with former defence minister Kevin Andrews to sit on the back bench side-by-side, separated by a narrow aisle.
A few minutes later former treasurer Joe Hockey arrived in a casual amble, right hand in pocket, to sit next to Mr Abbott.
In front of them sat Peter Hendy, the new Assistant Minister for Productivity. His home had been used as a meeting place for the campaign to remove Mr Abbott.
Tony Abbott accepted handshakes from many around him but kept a civil distance from Mr Hendy. Joe Hockey gave Mr Hendy a nod. But that was it.
Six places to their left and a row back, Bronwyn Bishop, the former Speaker, watched it grimly.
The House quickly got on with the serious matters of swearing in the new Liberal MJP for Canning Andrew Hastie, and mourning Curtis Cheng, the civilian police worker murdered by a terrorist in Parramatta.
Opposition leader Bill Shorten’s first question to Prime Minister Turnbull inquired along the lines of: You said Mr Abbott was a great Prime Minister, so why did you remove him?
“I am delighted that the leader of the opposition showing his gallantry has given me the opportunity once again to praise the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott),” said Mr Turnbull, crediting his predecessor with bringing to an end the “a period of reckless spending, dysfunctional” Labor government.
Questions about the fate of children in asylum seeker detention camps, debate over cuts to penalty rates, and anti-terrorist measures followed.
But silent attention also was given to the sight, uncommon in the Liberal Party, of three formerly senior ministers pretending to be busy on the backbench.
For most of the time their heads were bowed over paperwork, the frequent pose of those who like to indicate their life is too busy to totally make way for this routine parliamentary stuff.
Mr Abbott has not decided or announced whether he will stay in parliament. Mr Andrews is expected to remain. Mr Hockey has signalled his intention to quit, probably for the job of ambassador to Washington, and might give his valedictory speech next week.
 The walking wounded of politics
